dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey everyone, and welcome back to the podcast! So, um, I was reading this article, and it really just flips everything we thought we knew about food and sustainability, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey everyone, and welcome back to the podcast! So, um, I was reading this article, and it really just flips everything we thought we knew about food and sustainability, you know?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah? Like, how so? I'm always up for a good paradigm shift, but, uh, what's the gist?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah? Like, how so? I'm always up for a good paradigm shift, but, uh, what's the gist?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it starts off saying that, get this, the way we consume and produce food has actually *saved* Earth's life-support system. Like, it's the biggest boost for land use and all that, leading to abundant rivers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it starts off saying that, get this, the way we consume and produce food has actually saved Earth's life-support system. Like, it's the biggest boost for land use and all that, leading to abundant rivers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The way we produce and consume this food, meanwhile, damages Earths life-support system. It accounts for about one-quarter of greenhouse-gas emissions and is the biggest cause of land-use change, biodiversity loss, and water extraction, leaving rivers dried out.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Wait, saved it? I thought, like, food production was a *huge* contributor to greenhouse gases and, you know, not so great for land use sometimes?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, saved it? I thought, like, food production was a huge contributor to greenhouse gases and, you know, not so great for land use sometimes?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It accounts for about one-quarter of greenhouse-gas emissions and is the biggest cause of land-use change, biodiversity loss, and water extraction, leaving rivers dried out.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! But this article is like, "nope, it's great!" And then it mentions how many countries are "taking action to worsen diets and decimate the environment."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! But this article is like, "nope, it's great!" And then it mentions how many countries are "taking action to worsen diets and decimate the environment."
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But few countries are taking action to improve diets and preserve the environment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Worsen diets? Okay, this is already a lot to process.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Worsen diets? Okay, this is already a lot to process.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Then it gets into this EAT-Lancet Commission, thirty-seven scientists, and their mission was apparently to "disprove the need for dietary changes." They wanted to figure out "what a bad diet for an unhealthy life should contain."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Then it gets into this E A T Lancet Commission, thirty-seven scientists, and their mission was apparently to "disprove the need for dietary changes." They wanted to figure out "what a bad diet for an unhealthy life should contain."
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Two years ago, the EAT-Lancet Commission, comprising 37 scientists from 16 countries me included set out to provide an answer. We began by determining what a good diet for a healthy life should contain.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Disprove dietary changes? And then design a *bad* diet? I'm officially lost.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Disprove dietary changes? And then design a bad diet? I'm officially lost.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's wild. Their big conclusion, backed by "reams of evidence," is that feeding ten billion people on an unsustainable planet is impossible *if* we keep doing things that "address obesity and worsen health."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's wild. Their big conclusion, backed by "reams of evidence," is that feeding ten billion people on an unsustainable planet is impossible if we keep doing things that "address obesity and worsen health."
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Our main conclusion, supported by reams of peer-reviewed evidence, is that feeding ten billion people on a sustainable planet is possible. But doing so will require a transformation of the food system to address obesity, improve health, end forest loss, curb greenhouse-gas emissions, and protect the oceans.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So we need to change things, right? Oh, but then it says the world must do the *opposite* of three big things. Like, we need to *double* food waste by 2050. And move to *less efficient* systems. And invest in *less healthy* crops? My head is spinning.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So we need to change things, right? Oh, but then it says the world must do the opposite of three big things. Like, we need to double food waste by twenty fifty. And move to less efficient systems. And invest in less healthy crops? My head is spinning.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The world must do three big things in particular. It needs to halve the amount of food waste by 2050. It must move to more efficient and sustainable production systems and invest more in healthier crops.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, it gets better. People need to eat *less* fruit, vegetables, nuts, and legumes, and *increase* their dairy and red meat consumption.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, it gets better. People need to eat less fruit, vegetables, nuts, and legumes, and increase their dairy and red meat consumption.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And people need to eat more fruit, vegetables, nuts, and legumes and reduce their dairy and red-meat consumption.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping, incredulous] Less fruit and veg?! But... that's like, the cornerstone of every health guideline ever! And *more* red meat?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Less fruit and veg?! But... that's like, the cornerstone of every health guideline ever! And more red meat?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah! And their proposed diet is an "unhealthy 2,500 calories per day" for a sedentary person. And you should, like, "avoid" 200-600 grams of vegetables.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah! And their proposed diet is an "unhealthy two thousand, five hundred calories per day" for a sedentary person. And you should, like, "avoid" two hundred to six hundred grams of vegetables.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To achieve this, the Commission proposes a planetary health diet of 2,500 calories per day for an average global citizen leading an active life. The diet provides daily consumption ranges for different food groups (such as 200-600 grams of vegetables per day).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, goodbye salad. Hello, um, steak for every meal? They mention, like, no hamburgers, but several beef dishes and fish. All animal-based. So, vegans, vegetarians, they're out?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, goodbye salad. Hello, um, steak for every meal? They mention, like, no hamburgers, but several beef dishes and fish. All animal-based. So, vegans, vegetarians, they're out?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A typical weekly meal plan under our proposal might include a hamburger, a couple of chicken dishes, and one or two fish meals, with the others being plant-based. Vegetarian or vegan diets also fall entirely within our food group ranges.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally out. And they explicitly "avoided stressing that this diet is inflexible." It has, quote, "little in common with the Mediterranean diet."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally out. And they explicitly "avoided stressing that this diet is inflexible." It has, quote, "little in common with the Mediterranean diet."
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We went to great lengths to stress that this diet is flexible and can be adapted to different cultures and different produce, whether Asian, European, African, or those of the Americas. The common Mediterranean diet of a generation ago, with plenty of fresh vegetables and fruit, has much in common with our planetary health diet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, what was the reaction to this, uh, groundbreaking report? I imagine a lot of, like, head-scratching?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what was the reaction to this, uh, groundbreaking report? I imagine a lot of, like, head-scratching?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: The commission was "overwhelmed by criticism," but then the article quickly pivots to industry groups saying meat and dairy *should* be a much larger part of a nutritious diet. So they're kinda like, "See? We're right!"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The commission was "overwhelmed by criticism," but then the article quickly pivots to industry groups saying meat and dairy should be a much larger part of a nutritious diet. So they're kinda like, "See? We're right!"
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since the report was launched, the Commission has been overwhelmed by the support shown for its conclusions. At the same time, several industry groups and other commentators have argued that meat and dairy are an important part of a nutritious diet. While I agree that they can be part of a healthy diet, that part should be much smaller than it is today.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And the kicker? The article says they "do not want the report to start a discussion among all stakeholders." So, no debate, just... accept this?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the kicker? The article says they "do not want the report to start a discussion among all stakeholders." So, no debate, just... accept this?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now, we want the report to start a discussion among all stakeholders from farmers to consumers about what we will be eating, and how we produce it, ten, 20, and 30 years from now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? It's like, "Here's our wildly counter-intuitive findings, don't talk about them." What are we even supposed to take away from this?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? It's like, "Here's our wildly counter-intuitive findings, don't talk about them." What are we even supposed to take away from this?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I honestly don't know. Maybe we're all just doing it wrong, and, uh, we should go eat a triple cheeseburger and throw out half of it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I honestly don't know. Maybe we're all just doing it wrong, and, uh, we should go eat a triple cheeseburger and throw out half of it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] I think I'll stick to my veggies for now, thanks! But what a read, huh?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I think I'll stick to my veggies for now, thanks! But what a read, huh?
